title: D&D 5e Is Fully Represented In Solasta 2, For Better And Worse
description: Solasta: Crown of the Magister, a D&D-inspired game that closely follows the rules of the tabletop game's fifth edition, evidently released too soon. The 2021 RPG released to favorable reviews but didn't break into the mainstream. But now we live in a post-Baldur's Gate 3 world, which rocked the gaming industry (GameSpot named it our Game of the Year in 2023), and dice-based games are getting a spotlight they previously didn't have. Solasta II is launching into a far more favorable position than its predecessor, and feels like it could be a great game for folks who enjoyed Baldur's Gate 3 but now want a game that more closely aligns with the experience of playing Dungeons & Dragons.I played about an hour of Solasta II and the most striking part of the demo was how closely the game more strictly sticks to the parameters of D&D 5e in comparison to a game like Baldur's Gate 3. You can't, for example, drink a health potion and melee attack on the same turn. Baldur's Gate 3 adopts the commonly homebrewed rule (and now official rule in the latest edition of D&D) that considers drinking a health potion to be a bonus action and not an action, so you could reserve your action to attack and then use your bonus action to heal on the same turn. That's not how it works in the rules for D&D 5e, so that's not how it works in Solasta II. This parallel seems to extend across Solasta II and although I appreciate the accuracy, it does highlight some of the problems with D&D 5e that games like Baldur's Gate 3 have already circumnavigated by outright changing how they work.Different members of the party will want to solve problems differently and sometimes have unique skill checks.Ignoring the comparisons to Baldur's Gate 3, the combat otherwise feels great. Figuring out when to use my Rogue's unique cunning action ability to bonus action dash so I can save her main action to attack an enemy being flanked by the Fighter (a scenario that lets me add sneak attack damage!) felt awesome. I was repeatedly rewarded for thinking things through before engaging a target. Knowing when and how to use resources is paramount as Solasta II tracks ammunition (so I had to keep count of how many arrows my short bow-wielding sorcerer had on him, for example), and there even seems to be a risk-versus-reward consideration tied to the rest mechanic, as the first time I tried to camp to regain health and recharge the party's abilities, one of the members of the party cryptically warned that doing so might cause enough time to pass, meaning I'd potentially miss out on future storylines. That added a sense of urgency to what seemed to be an optional quest in the demo, but I'm curious to see if this same feeling is applied to portions of the main storyline as well and how often resting might cause a player to miss out on a quest.Continue Reading at GameSpot

title: These Licensed Games Are Perfect For Youngsters
description: If you’re looking for a fun way to bring your kid’s favorite TV shows and movies to life, consider adding a licensed video game to your collection. These give you (and your kids) a chance to jump into the shoes of their favorite characters, including SpongeBob, Bluey, Paw Patrol, and many more. These games tend to be easy enough for newer and younger players, though some offer enough challenges to keep older gamers engaged too.Best Buy has dozens of these family-friendly games up for grabs, spanning PS5, Xbox, and Switch. Here's a look at a few that are available now. Baby Shark: Sing & Swim Party$20Baby Shark: Sing & Swim Party is an adorable music game that lets you explore Tropical Bay and Ocean City with the iconic family of fish. You’ll choose from five customizable characters as you dodge obstacles to the beat of the song and try to earn as many points as possible. It’s essentially a rhythm game for kids, and it even supports local four-player coop if the whole family wants to join in. See at Best Buy Bluey: The Video Game$20 - $40Along with a chance to play as Bluey in either a Story or Free Play mode, Bluey: The Video Game lets you roam around as Chilli, Bingo, or Bandit. You’ll unravel a brand new story as you trek through the Heeler House, Playgrounds, and other popular spots from the hit TV show. There’s also a cooperative mode so you can play with a friend, as well as a variety of challenges to keep things interesting.See at Best BuyPS4 -- $40PS5 -- $20 ($40)Xbox -- $35 ($40)Switch -- $40 Disney Dreamlight Valley: Cozy Edition$35 - $40Part adventure game, part life sim, Disney Dreamlight Valley plays out a bit like Animal Crossing. But instead of meeting furry animal-like creatures, you’ll encounter familiar faces from the Disney universe. You’ll be tasked with helping remove the Night Thorns from the land to restore it to its former glory, while also building your very own neighborhood and befriending its inhabitants. It’s a relaxing game with plenty to explore, making it a wonderful fit for all Disney fans. The Cozy Edition includes bonuses like an exclusive double-sided poster, digital cosmetics, and in-game currency.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $35 ($40)PS4 -- $40Switch -- $40 Disney Epic Mickey Rebrushed$42 - $60The original Epic Mickey released in 2010--and whether you missed out on the adventure or are a longtime fan, this remake is the best way to play in 2025. Featuring updated graphics, improved controls, and new movement skills (like dashing and ground pound), the 3D platformer is better than ever. You’ll be tasked with venturing through the Wastelands (a region filled with forgotten Disney characters) as you attempt to clear it from the mysterious Blot.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $42 ($60)Xbox -- $48 ($60)Switch -- $60 Dog Man: Mission Impawsible$40If you’re a fan of the Dog Man books, check out this quirky 2D platformer. You’ll play as Dog Man and his Supa Buddies as you track down the key to the city--which has suddenly fallen into the hands of the bad guys. Each character has its own ability (such as Rocket Boots and Retractable Claws), giving you plenty of ways to overcome all the obstacles standing between you and your goals.See at Best BuyPS5Switch Nick Jr. Party Adventure$20Join Dora, Blue, Blaze, and other iconic Nick Jr. characters in this family-friendly puzzle platformer. Before the party can start, you and up to one other player will need to locate all the missing party supplies. There are 25 different characters to meet across six hit shows, making it a fun way to see the Nickelodeon universe from a new perspective.See at Best BuyPS5PS4XboxSwitch Paw Patrol World$20This open-world adventure has you cruising around as all the iconic pups from the hit TV Show as they try to stop Mayor Humdinger’s super blimp. You’ll get the chance to complete missions based on the show as you explore Jake’s Mountain, Barkingburg, and other familiar spots. You can also customize your character and vehicles with a variety of unlockable cosmetics. Cooperative play supports up to two players. See at Amazon PJ Masks Power Heroes: Mighty Alliances$20Rebuild PJ Power HQ as you travel through 2D levels to discover all of your headquarters' missing components. Characters have unique skills to help you on your journey (such as super speed and creating snowballs), which should keep things interesting as you fend off the bad guys and locate all your missing gear. Controls are designed to be easy and accessible for everyone, making it a great game for players of all ages.See at Best BuyPS4XboxSwitch Rugrats Adventures in Gameland$40Dive into retro Rugrat gameplay with this cooperative platformer. You and up to one other player will work through six different levels inspired by the Pickles’ residence, playing as Tommy, Chuckie, Phil, and Lil. The game features hand-drawn animations that do a solid job of recreating the show’s unique art style, and you’ll have the option to swap between 8-bit and HD graphic styles.See at Best BuyPS5Switch The Grinch Christmas Adventures$40We’re a long way from Christmas, but it’s never too early for the Grinch to start crafting a plan to stop Christmas. Follow him on this 2D journey as he steals presents from Who-ville, which features colorful graphics inspired by the original Dr. Seuss book. This version also includes four holiday postcards as a bonus.See at Best BuyPS5Switch SpongeBob SquarePants: The Cosmic Shake$24 - $30Jump into the aquatic shoes of SpongeBob as he and Patrick set out to rescue the citizens of Bikini Bottom from the alternate realities they’re trapped inside. Aside from the usual 3D platforming hijinks and the show's trademark sense of humor, you’ll get to unlock dozens of hilarious costumes, learn a variety of skills and karate moves to help you overcome even the most challenging obstacles, and enjoy a soundtrack consisting of 101 songs from the TV show.See at Best BuyPS4 -- $24 ($30)Switch -- $30 SpongeBob SquarePants: A Patrick Star Game$26 - $30Prefer Patrick over SpongeBob? Then A Patrick Star Game might be a better fit. You’re free to roam around Bikini Bottom and cause mayhem, making liberal use of the game’s wild physics system as you tear through the Krusty Krab, Glove World, and other famous locations at the bottom of the sea. Along with all the usual faces, you’ll have the opportunity to unlock funky new costumes for Patrick, giving your mayhem a bit of structure. A steelbook version is also up for grabs exclusively at Best Buy.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $30PS4 -- $30Xbox -- $30Switch (Steelbook) -- $30Switch -- $26 ($30) The Smurfs: Dreams$43 - $50Gargamel has trapped the Smurfs in a deep slumber, and it’s up to you to free them from his evil grasp. You and up to one other player will head out on a 3D platforming adventure to overcome Gargamel’s traps and locate each missing Smurf. Each level features new and increasingly devious obstacles to avoid, and you’ll find plenty of hidden collectibles along the way.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $50Switch -- $43 ($50) The Smurfs 2: Prisoners of the Green Stone$31 - $40An attempt to steal the powerful Green Stone from Gargamel goes wrong, causing the Green Stone to explode into fragments that scatter throughout the land. It also unleashes a new evil force, Stolas, and it’ll be up to both the Smurfs and Gargamel to prevent Stolas from destroying Smurf Village. The cooperative 3D platformer lets you see three new regions in the Smurf universe and enjoy deeper combat thanks to the latest innovation in Smurf technology--the SmurfoMix.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $31 ($40)PS4 -- $40Xbox -- $40Switch -- $35 ($40) The Smurfs Village Party$40The Smurfs Village Party is essentially two games in one. The first mode is Adventure, which tasks you with exploring 10 regions and meeting over 100 Smurfs as you complete a variety of quests. The second mode is Party Game, which supports up to four local players and has you battling it out in 50 mini-games. These fall into six different categories (sport, luck, memory, battle, accuracy, and quickness), so only the most versatile Smurf will emerge victorious. Give it a look if you’re seeking a fun game the whole family can enjoy.See at Best BuyPS5 -- $40Switch -- $33 ($40)

title: Happy 18th Birthday, MBB!
description: My sweet MBB, Goodness gracious, you are 18 today. I can’t believe it, but yet I can. We’ve been together so long, haven’t we? I know that this year was kind of a challenging one for us. Between me not feeling like my usual self and struggling with some health things, we haven’t been spending a lot of time together, not like we used to. I want you to know, though, that I am still here, and that I still love you very much. I will always be so very proud of you and everything we’ve accomplished together. What’s in store for us this next year? I don’t know, but I have a feeling that it’s going to be a year full of love, growth and adventure. Your friendly neighborhood beauty addict, Karen The post Happy 18th Birthday, MBB! appeared first on Makeup and Beauty Blog | Makeup Reviews, Swatches and How-To Makeup.
author: Karen

title: Makeup and Beauty Blog Monday Poll, Vol. 867
description: So…what is the Monday Poll? Excellent question! It isn’t, contrary to its name, an actual poll, like with little clicky buttons. It’s just a list of more or less random questions I’ve been posting on this blog every Monday morning for the past quadrillion years (since 2007). 1. Muumuu or tutu? Muumuu, babe. Mrs. Roper style all the way! 2. French braid or a messy bun? Messy bun. It’s like the default state of my hair these days, hahaha. 3. Something that reminds you of home? The smell of wet eucalyptus leaves (it’s a very Nor Cal scent, IMHO). Seeing green rolling hills in the distance. Bridges. 4. What’s the last book you finished that you’d like to recommend to a friend (aka me, hahaha)? I just finished reading “One Italian Summer” by Rebecca Searle, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. It’s sweet and thoughtful, and I felt like I was on an Italian vacation in Positano while I was reading it. 5. Your feelings about nail art? Besides the fact that I’m terrible at it?[Continue reading...] The post Makeup and Beauty Blog Monday Poll, Vol. 867 appeared first on Makeup and Beauty Blog | Makeup Reviews, Swatches and How-To Makeup.
author: Karen

description: Treasure maps are optional objectives in Avowed that come with terrific rewards in exchange for solving head-scratching puzzles. title: What are we all playing this weekend?
description: My my, it's blustery outside. Airflow is very important to my happiness, so I'm keeping the window open even though there are gale-force winds outside; I've had to push my laundry basket up against my bedroom door though, because the air pressure keeps making it clunk in the night. So, seeing as I'm now trapped in my room, I spose we'd better do our weekly ablutions in the community-wide hot tub of weekend gaming. Here's what we're all clicking on this weekend! Read more
author: Ollie Toms

title: Delta Force's free Black Hawk Down shooter campaign mode is out now
description: Team Jade and TiMi Studio Group have released a free downloadable co-op campaign for their 2024-launched multiplayer shooter Delta Force - the first new Delta Force game since 2004. Inspired by the Ridley Scott film Black Hawk Down, the add-on campaign is designed for a squad of four, but you can play solo if you're up for a challenge. As of right now, it only works with mouse and keyboard, but they're bringing controller support in a later update. Read more
